Posts.Content: Over Christmas I had 2 unexpected long drives ..the first to collect one of my GDs & the other to take her back ...in between I looked after her...as she was heavily pregnant.  All went well with her & she gave birth to a beautiful baby boy 31st Dec.  I had a couple of incidents of palpitations & mentioned it last Tues when I was in the Unit for my 8th Herceptin.  Major panic amongst the staff...& a 10 lead ECG & print outs sent up to cardiology.  Result was OK to have injection. I already had Echocardiogram booked for this Monday...so that will show up the situation properly.  Slightly concerned...won't get results until I see specialist Nurse following Monday....
Posts.Title: Palpitations / GreatGrandson / Herceptin

Posts.Content: TY Carolyn,  I knew about Herceptin & it damaging the heart. ....each Echo I have a worry that I'm going to be under the 'magic line' & have to have a break between injections.  About 7/8 years ago I had several bouts of palpitations & saw a Cardiologist privately through a scheme I belong to.  He said they were noticeable because of the amount of caffeine I was drinking. He also said I had Left Atrial Fibrulation & although I didn't need medication I should have a check every year.  I have asked 2 different GPs at my previous practice as well as my current GP & they have said that his letter to them says no such thing!!  ?? Cardiologist thinking I'd go privately every year?? I will explain to the Echo person tomorrow that I need some info....   At 68 ...69 at the beginning of March....I sincerely hope I do not have a heart problem as well as the cancer!
Posts.Title: Palpitations / GreatGrandson / Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi Bougiecat,  Thanks for your kind message. I can't wait to see my new GreatGrandson...they live a fair distance away & I found the drive very stressful...i am going to look into going 1 day & staying overnight somewhere & driving back the next day but due to comitments including caring for my 8yo GD while her parents are at work it gets complicated!  I had a standard 'chemo' blood rest this afternoon but will note to ask if potassium was included when I see my chemo nurse next week.  Thanks for the heads up on that!  Give your Great Grandson a hug from me!
Posts.Title: Palpitations / GreatGrandson / Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn,  I did not get a copy of the letter but I can trust my current GP who is a friend through GirlGuiding. When the cardiologist said it was probably due to too much caffeine I stopped all coffee immediately & then had the mother & father of all headaches due to the suddenness of stopping!  I then drank coffee but started swapping full caff to decaff 1'cup a day at a time & gradually weaned myself off full caff.  I have now also cut down the number of decaff coffees I have & drink a wider selection of hot & cold drinks.  Thanks for kind thoughts & responding to my post.
Posts.Title: Palpitations / GreatGrandson / Herceptin

Posts.Content: Very interesting!  My mother had a thyroid problem ...not sure which... Every blood test which has included thyroid test has come back as "OK" ...there was one which was 'out of line' but GP put it down to a glitch.  Not sure how to send F/R through this ...will look & see what I can find....
Posts.Title: Palpitations / GreatGrandson / Herceptin

Posts.Content: I am in the middle of chemo.  I asked both at the Chemo Unit & my GP about the 'flu jab. Both came back with a resounding yes.  I was told to arrange it as close to just before any chemo session.  You are best to check with hour Oncologist just in case there is any reason why you should not have it.
Posts.Title: Flu jab and chemo

Posts.Content: Hi you wonderful people. I was diagnosed with BC Feb 2016  as the result of a routine mammogram— I had no signs or symptoms.  I opted for mastectomy & they took 1 lymph node which was clear.  Next came 4 rounds of TC then 17 ( 1 year) injections of Herceptin accompanied by Tamoxifen (18 months) When my Oncologist saw me last he said  1) in January I am to swap from Tamoxifen & start Anastrozole...for 10 years.  2) I was very fortunate that I had that mammogram when I did ....6 months later & it would have been a different story.... So ladies.....anyone any info on this change of drugs...?? TYIA
Posts.Title: Swapping from Tamoxifen to Anastrozole

Posts.Content: Hi,  Well done for getting this far.  I have had annual mammograms but also 6 monthly checkups with the Breast Care Nurse.  I think this continues for a certain no. of years post diagnosis.  When I was discharged from the Oncology Unit to the care of the BCN & my GP I attended my local Daycare Hospice once a week & participated in their education programme.  I was then selected to do a HOPE course with them ...can’t remember what HOPE stands for but it is a 6 week programme developed by Macmillan in conjunction with Coventry University.  It has helped me move on & cope better with the next stage of treatment...Anastrozole for the next 8.5 years. (was 9 yrs but started in Jan ) I saw the Plastic Surgeon very recently about a reduction to make me symmetrical. Waiting to hear if the Hospital will allow him to go ahead...he was very positive ...there is a 3-4 month waiting list. He cannot operate until my BMI is below 30 anyway.  Last Nov. my BMI was 36.2 I have got it down to 30.1 ...my next target is to get it to 25.  Keep smiling! It confuses everyone!!
Posts.Title: Screening once treatment is all finished

Posts.Content: I skimmed the article ...what more does anyone expect from the Daily Fail?
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I discussed this with my D-in-L last night while she took  me shopping ....she was appalled...& said that it is not brave....just very insensitive.  We agreed about those with very long hair having a bob & donating their hair for others to have a wig...if they wish to do so ...but no pressure should be put on anyone with long hair to do this.  My hair has almost all gone ...but I delight in seeing my young Granddaughter's long flowing locks. ...& know that my hair will eventually grow back.  In the mean time ...I go for my first wig appointment next week ... I'm thinking     Bright pink .... not sure of style ....  I see my loss of hair as my badge for fighting the Evil Worm called Cancer.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Thank you for commenting, Jess & for take ng our comments back to the fundraising team.  I and others realise how difficult it is to come up with new ideas each year to raise money & awaeness.  Perhaps in future they could consider asking a group of people living with & fighting cancer for their views.  I have a friend who had cancer a few years ago & lost her hair ...when it started to grow back she had it dyed bright pink...so when I heard the words 'cancer' & 'chemo' in the same sentence from the Breast Care team at the hospital the words that came into my mind were 'mastectomy' & 'if I'm going to lose my hair I'm having it dyed pink NOW!'  I have been open & honest with friends & acquaintances...my hair has almost all gone & I am having my first wig appointment this week ....bright pink YES !! style ...??? not sure yet ....  There is nothing brave about it ...I want people to know so I can tell them that my cancer was found as a result of a routine mammogram....& even when they had done the core biopsy & I knew where the cancer was   I STILL COULD NOT FEEL IT!  If I had not kept that appointment the cancer would not have been found in time as there was 1 x 17mm lump & several 'seedlings'
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Since I put up the message last night I have had loads of people 'like' my post & lots of positive comments.  Some have mentioned the long to short hair & donation of the hair to The Little Princess Trust ....  Thanks for the 'right words' to use ... My mind had gone to mush particularly over this horrible side effect ...  Everyone thinks I'm doing well & embracing the hair loss ...but it is the first thing that brings tears to my eyes....I have always taken care of how my hair looks etc ..
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: When I was diagnosed with Breast Cancer one of my first thoughts was that I was going to lose my hair.  I decided to have it died pink before it went & it was useful to start the conversation with people about my cancer.  I had a mastectomy & have just had round 2 of TC chemo.  During round 1 my hair started to come out in handfulls ...so my stylist gave me a grade 7 shave ....& I looked rather like Judi Dench... Now I wake up to what looks like dog hair over my pillow.  I've got an appointment next week for a first wig fitting.  I have been trying, & generally succeeding, to be brave about losing my hair.  THEN CAME ALONG THIS STUPID CAMPAIGN!  It has angered me no end...  I do hope that this campaign can be stopped.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I'm not going to repeat my objections to the campaign...I have voiced them several times.  What I also object to is the way MacMillan state that they need the money 'because no one should face cancer alone'  My GP told me the Hospital would allocate me a MacMillan Nurse....when I asked at the hospital when this would happen they said that I did not need one! The only people who are allocated a MacMillan Nurse are those needing palliative / end of life care.  I do not have a specific Nurse allocated to me in the Chemo unit.  The whole team are very great & caring but there is no one I can talk to who knows about my medical situation.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Thanks for this ....hope you don't mind but rather than reinvent the wheel ...I have used your post ....particularly as you have put the case so eloquently. Xxx
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I have not seen the advert on FB yet.... If I do I will also hide it & am strongly tempted to put a message as my status warning that anyone who does this is not my friend.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: My surgeon warned me that if they could not trace the radioactive whatsit they would need to use blue dye....ie wake up looking like a smurf & my urine would be green.  When I saw him after the op I mentioned that he had not needed to use the dye...& he said..that he was pleased that hadn't happened because he liked my pink hair & didn't want to be responsible for turning it purple!
Posts.Title: Green boob!

Posts.Content: Hi Lyn,  When I had my last Herceptin I was a mess...I was being discharged from the Oncology Unit where I had been looked after & made friends with the staff.  They refered me to the local Day Hospice...& I have been going there virtually every week since then & done the education sessions through twice.  They have just started offering the HOPE Course...6 sessions of 2 1/2 hours. Last week was my first week & it went very well. I am looking forward to tomorrow’s session. We have a small group & 2 Nurses as deliverers / facilitators. The HOPE Course has been complied by Macmillan in conjunction with Coventry University.
Posts.Title: Moving Forward Course, Breast Cancer Care, anyone done the course

Posts.Content: Hi there,  I live alone too. I have always been a very independent person....I am usually the person everyone else goes to for help.  My son came with me to the first critical appointments.  After that once News got around there were so many genuine offers of help that I felt really humbled & I resolved to ask people in turn....to help me.  In this way I can contact someone & ask for a lift & if they can't do it they know I have a long list of people to ask...if no friend is available then the fall back position is that my son would have to take time off work or send one of the people who work for him!  I have people phone or email reminding me of their offers of help.  Some visit for a cuppa....they know which cupboards things are in & how I like my drinks!  My stylist has been magnificent...she initially cut my hair shorter 'for the summer' & when I was finding handfulls of hair she shaved it to give me a "Judi Dench" hairstyle....& did not charge me...  Learning to ask for & accept help has been hard, but well worth while!
Posts.Title: Living alone and having chemo
